awd_titl_txt: Chemical, Electrochemical and Physical Properties of Metallosupramolecular Architectures with Neutral and Radical Bridging Ligands and the Influence of Non-Covalent Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
From common refrigerator magnets to tiny magnetic particles on which data are recorded in hard drives, magnets are pervasive in everyday life. The reduction in size of magnetic particles over the past several decades has led to significant increase in the storage capacity but the limit is being reached.  Professor Dunbar's group at Texas A&M University Main Campus explores new types of chemical structures that display magnetic behavior at the nanoscale level.  Through systematic investigation of the structure-property relationships of these magnetic compounds, the team aims to gain a better fundamental understanding of the factors that contribute to superior magnetic properties and provide insight to inform design of the next generation magnets for computing or electronic storage devices.  The versatility of skills required to work on this project is an excellent opportunity for students, including members of underrepresented groups, to learn chemical synthesis as well as numerous methods of characterization. 

The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Chemistry Division supports Prof. Dunbar's group to synthesize and study the properties of multinuclear transition and lanthanide metal supramolecular architectures with neutral and radical bridging ligands.  Whereas more commonly used closed-shell (diamagnetic) bridging ligands engage in superexchange (indirect) interactions between the metal spins, radical bridging ligands facilitate direct exchange interactions which results in much stronger magnetic coupling.  For transition metal complexes, this situation results in modest coupling and in lanthanide complexes these interactions are very weak. Magnetic coupling in both transition metal complexes and lanthanide rare earth complexes is greatly improved by using a radical bridging ligand that can engage in direct exchange with the metal ions.  In order to further improve upon these systems, the Dunbar group seeks to generate new classes of radical-bridged magnetic complexes using supramolecular strategies.  This project focuses on using N-heterocyclic neutral ligands that feature interactions between anions and electron deficient aromatic rings, namely the anion-pi interaction.  The neutral ligand can undergo a reversible one-electron reduction at accessible potentials to form a stable radical.   Computatonal studies are performed to identify the most synthetically feasible targets and guide the direction of research as it progresses.  Spontaneous self-assembly of paramagnetic metal ions with the ligands gives multinuclear supramolecular complexes in high yields due to anion and solvent templates.  A plethora of techniques (including single-crystal X-ray crystallography, SQUID magnetometry, electrochemistry, and electron paramagnetic resonance) is used to study the rich electronic, redox, and magnetic properties of these supramolecular architectures.  By comparing the properties of the complexes with a variety of ligands with different electron donating ability and coordinating geometry, this research aims to unveil the structural and electronic factors that contribute to superior magnetic coupling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

Bistable molecular materials, characterized by two nearly degenerate states, have emerged as promising candidates for next-generation applications in molecular-based electronics, switches, and high-density data storage devices. These materials, particularly single-molecule magnets (SMMs), which exhibit magnetic bistability akin to traditional magnets, and redox non-innocent (NI) compounds are being targeted for these efforts. Notably, non-innocent organic molecules (molecules that can readily lose or gain electrons)  linked to metal ions are playing a pivotal role in the exploration of bistable magnetic materials. This project delved into the design and development of redox-active organic building blocks for incorporation into multinuclear SMMs and NI metal compounds.

Key findings:

Non-innocent bridging ligands were selected from a comprehensive group of redox-active organic molecules to assess their utility for the design of bistable molecular materials. A pyrene-based organic molecule in the tetraone family, known for its four stable redox states, was used to prepare three homologous dinuclear transition metal complexes of  iron, cobalt and nickel. A synergistic approach, incorporating both experimental and theoretical analyses, was employed to ascertain the unique redox activity across this series. The slightly different crystal structures of the three compounds unveiled varying degrees of redox-induced electron transfer (RIET) from the metal ions to the organic linker. The degree of RIET is the least for the nickel compound, with the oxidation state of the nickel centers and the linker remaining unchanged. In contrast, a complete RIET was observed for the cobalt analogue. Static and dynamic magnetic measurements fully supported the assignment of redox states predicted from the crystal structures. To further investigate how the RIET affects the electrochemical properties of the compounds, cyclic voltammetry (CV) and differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) studies were conducted as well.

Spin-crossover (SCO) is another type of magnetic bistability that can be achieved in molecular materials. In these compounds the number of unpaired electrons changes with temperature or under light irradiation. Solid-state assemblies of these molecules, combined with other functional organic moieties such as the well-known tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) electron acceptor, can result in an enhancement of the original properties and/or coexistence/synergistic interactions of more than one functionality. One goal of this project was to explore ways to manipulate solid-state structures and physical properties of SMMs and SCO compounds by manipulating supramolecular interactions between TCNQ and SCO/SMM units for potential applications in electronic devices. The two main types of molecular magnetic bistability, (SMM and SCO) were achieved with the same cationic cobalt complex by using slightly different anion radicals, namely TCNQ(-1) and TCNQF(-1). Single crystal structures and theoretical studies revealed that supramolecular interactions play important roles in tuning the magnetic properties. A mixed-stacked of partially charged TCNQ (electron acceptor) and the phenothiazinyl (PTZ, electron donor) group on the SCO molecule was achieved in one of the cobalt compounds by introducing charge transfer interactions between conducting and SCO building blocks. The temperature dependent solid-state structures as well as the magnetic and conducting properties were compared to the non-SCO zinc analogue, the results of which revealed that synergistic behavior of SCO and electron transfer occurs between different TCNQ stacks for the cobalt material - this situation also promotes semiconducting behavior. These results demonstrate that introducing supramolecular interactions is a promising way to manipulate solid-state structures in the pursuit of interesting synergistic effects between different functionalities.

In another study, new nitrogen heterocyclic organic molecules were synthesized with the objective of designing multinuclear transition metal and lanthanide metal SMMs. Two novel multinuclear clusters, Ni6 and  Dy4, featuring non-radical forms of the designed ligands were isolated. Strategies were also pursued for synthesizing multinuclear radical-bridged SMMs using these innovative ligands.

Numerous other materials with stable organic molecules that possess unpaired electrons were also synthesized and studied over the course of the funding period.  These results as well as the aforementioned ones were published in high profile journals or are in preparation for submission.

Broader Impacts:  

- Educated Ph.D. students and undergraduates in the burgeoning area of soft molecular materials and the study of their electronic, redox and magnetic peoperties.

- Mentored students in oral and written communication by requiring weekly group meeting presentations and the preparation of complete drafts of manuscripts which the PI read and returned for corrections/clarifications until the final draft was polished and ready for submission.

- Provided a teamwork environment for students to help one another and to share their expertise with other members of the research group. 

- Encouraged students to independently problem solve and to challenge commonly held beliefs that are constantly shifting as chemists learn more about new types of metal-organic materials. 

The activities of this project constitute excellent vehicles for preparing students to conduct multidisciplinary research in a variety of areas of chemistry and materials science, whether they choose to work in industry, academia, or the provate sector.

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2024
Modified by: Kim R Dunbar
